awd_titl_txt: Probing Strong Electronic Correlations in Ferroelectrics and Multiferroics Through High-Order Harmonic Spectroscopy and First-Principles Calculations
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Abstract: One of the goals of modern condensed matter physics is to control the properties of materials so that they can be modified 'on demand'. In relevant materials intense pulses of laser light can force the materials far from equilibrium, dramatically changing their electronic, magnetic, and optical properties. This work focuses on experimental and computational studies of the non-equilibrium properties of such materials which exhibit unique electronic and magnetic responses to external stimuli, induced by intense infrared laser fields. Using advanced laser techniques, the dynamics of interactions in such materials are reconstructed from measurements of light emitted through a process known as high-order harmonic generation. While most previous studies of ultrafast dynamics in solids are performed at the femtosecond and longer timescales (1 femtosecond = 0.000000000000001 seconds), this project seeks to uncover details of the sub-femtosecond dynamics and to establish the link between ultrafast interactions in non-equilibrium materials and the spectral- and time-domain structure of high-order harmonic emission. The experimental and theoretical tools developed through this project can also be used to describe processes relevant to technological applications such as solar energy and spintronics. Students trained as a result of the award will gain experience in advanced laser and computational techniques, as well as state-of-the-art materials synthesis, preparing them for high-tech careers.

Technical Abstract: Understanding and controlling the quantum many-body dynamics of strongly-driven, strongly-correlated materials is one of the grand challenges of modern science. Although the nonequilibrium dynamics of strongly-correlated materials have been studied for decades, the few- to sub-femtosecond dynamics of strong electronic correlation have been hidden from experiments. Through measurements and first-principles calculations of the high-order harmonics generated from intense mid-infrared laser fields in bulk and thin-film solids, this project aims to resolve electronic correlations in ferroelectric barium titanate and multiferroic bismuth ferrite crystals, and the role of these correlations in the strong-field laser response. Through measurements of the spectrum, polarization, and time-domain structure of the emitted high-order harmonic radiation, the project reveals the impacts of crystal structure and ferroelectric polarization, Berry curvature, and correlated electron dynamics on the high-order harmonic generation process. Calculations, using time-dependent density functional theory with exchange-correlation functions obtained via dynamical mean-field theory, accurately capture the time-domain Coulomb interactions at the heart of strong electronic correlations. The experimental and theoretical tools developed through this project can also be used to describe processes relevant to technological applications such as solar energy and spintronics. Students trained as a result of the award will gain experience in advanced laser and computational techniques, as well as state-of-the-art materials synthesis, preparing them for high-tech careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project "Probing Strong Electronic Correlations in Ferroelectrics and Multiferroics through High-Order Harmonic Spectroscopy and First-Principles Calculations" applied a combination of first-principles theory and experiments employing femtosecond (10-15 s), mid-infrared laser pulses to study the femtosecond and sub-femtosecond dynamics of materials driven by intense laser fields. The goals of the project were to understand the role played by electron correlation - the interaction of multiple electrons within a material - in determining both the static properties of materials and the outcomes of intense laser interactions with those materials. The project focused on certain insulating materials exhibiting controllable permanent electric and/or magnetic polarization, known as ferroelectrics and multiferroics. Specifically, the experimental studies focused on ferroelectric crystals BaTiO3 (barium titanate) and LiNbO3 (lithium niobate), while the theory studies focused on BaTiO3 and multiferroic BiFeO3 (bismuth ferrite). In both cases, the harmonics from these materials were compared with those from ZnO, a well-studied non-ferroelectric insulator exhibiting a permanent dipole moment along its optic axis.

Intellectual Merit: The project resulted in the generation of new knowledge regarding the interaction of intense laser fields with materials, and in particular the role played by electron-electron correlations in determining both the static properties and the dynamic light-matter interactions in strongly-correlated materials. A new code for simulating HHG spectra from strongly-correlated materials was developed. This code, which uses sophisticated electronic structure calculations and includes the dynamical electron-electron interaction through the Dynamical Mean Field Theory (DMFT), allows detailed calculations of the harmonic spectrum and other experimental observables. Several new phenomena were observed both in the experiments and calculated results, including the discovery of hysteresis effects in HHG from ferroelectric materials and the generation of "super-harmonics" - energy-periodic enhancement and suppression of the emitted harmonics - which arise due to the dynamic interactions of multiple electrons within a system.

Broader Impacts: The studies of electron-electron correlation in materials have the potential to lead to new light sources and optoelectronic devices based on intense laser interactions with quantum materials and the use of lasers to control material properties. Already, the work has influenced the development of new technology for the measurement of optical laser fields, which can be used to characterize the properties of laser pulses (pulse duration, frequency chirp, carrier-envelope phase) over a wide range of parameter space. The project has allowed the training of graduate and undergraduate students who contribute to racial/ethnic and gender diversity in physics, as well as graduate students from developing countries. The experiment/theory collaboration allowed students involved in the porject to gain a more diverse base of knowledge than they otherwise would, thus enhancing their ability to contribute to a high-tech workforce. The project has enabled collaborations among experts in laser technology and ultrafast spectroscopy, advanced theory, and epitaxial film growth and characterization, and has therefore allowed students trained on this project to gain experience outside of their field of expertise.
